intro: Leobordea quinata, commonly known as the Mexican sunflower, is a species of flowering plant native to Mexico and parts of Central America. It is characterized by its striking orange to red tubular flowers and lance-shaped leaves. The plant is a member of the Asteraceae family, which includes daisies and sunflowers, and is known for its ability to thrive in full sun. It typically grows as an annual or biennial plant, reaching heights of up to 2 meters. Leobordea quinata is often cultivated for its ornamental value and is also used in traditional medicine.
